description: Tour of stations designed by Charles Holden for the 1932 Piccadilly line extension north of Finsbury Park The stations demonstrate Holden's modernist vision and simple yet beautiful designs, which mark a new era in Underground architecture.

factsheet.heading: History - Background of the Piccadilly line extension
paragraphs:
The economic downturn of the late 1920s resulted
in increased unemployment. To combat this
increasing unemployment, the Government passed
the Development Act in July 1929. This Bill
subsidised capital improvement works of local
authorities and public bodies - including London
Underground.
At this time, the Piccadilly line terminated at
Finsbury Park, where commuters would transfer to
local tram and bus services. However, the station
had significant congestion, and there was a public
campaign to extend the line northward.
The Underground managed to obtain the rights and
government funding for extending the Piccadilly line
in June 1930, beginning construction later that
year. Many of the station sjavascript:;ites almost chose
themselves, as they were locations in which
existing bus routes converged. Construction of the line involved both tunnelling and surface construction.
When the first section of the extension opened in
September 1932, the Underground promoted the
new line to residents by distributing 30,000 free
return tickets from Piccadilly Circus station.

factsheet.heading: Architect Charles Holden
paragraphs:
From the 1920s to the 1940s, Charles Holden was responsible for the design of more than 50 stations and associated buildings across the Underground network. Holden’s station exteriors are architecturally striking and immediately identifiable with the Underground. He was a master of creating interiors that felt generous despite their
often limited spaces.
Holden was already a renowned architect and a
partner in the firm of Adams Holden & Pearson when
he began a design partnership with Frank Pick, who
would eventually become Managing Director of the
Underground. The two were members of the Design
and Industries Association (DIA), sharing an
appreciation of ‘fitness for purpose’.

Holden’s first major commission was the 1926 Northern line extension to Morden, followed by high profile
work on the Underground’s head office at 55 Broadway and
Piccadilly Circus, a showcase station for the Underground.

Holden’s designs for the Piccadilly line extensions of
1932 and 1933 were influenced by the work of
architects in Northern Europe, which Holden and Pick
visited on a 1930 study tour. Inspired by the buildings
on that tour, Holden based his designs for the
extension in a foundation of utilitarian materials -
brick, concrete, and glass - set in clean geometric
configurations.
These designs are deceptively simple. What on paper
looks like a collection of lines is transformed when
built into soaring spaces flooded with natural light,
creating environments that inspire calmness and
peace in those traveling on the Underground.
Holden’s work on the Cockfosters extension largely
falls into two types of building - the Sudbury Box,
which is essentially a rectangular brick structure with a
concrete lid, and the drum, in which circular forms
and shapes take precedence.
The advent of the Second World War and the
retirement of Pick effectively ended Holden’s
collaboration with the Underground, but his legacy
can still be felt across the network.
